summary.p: Bullinger received today the letter from the people of Augsburg [No. 2204], concerning the appointment of Matthias Erb [to Augsburg]. So far, as the [Augsburg] city clerk Georg Fr√∂lich knows, he has done his utmost in this matter, and he will continue to be committed to it. He will carefully carry out what the people of Augsburg [requested] in their letter, and he will promptly inform the [people of Augsburg] of [Erb's] response.

div.p: Heinrich Bullinger's reply to Augsburg, concerning Matthias Erb.
Learned, noble, steadfast, pious, prudent, honorable and wise, gracious, dear sirs, my entire willing service along with the offer of all good things is beforehand ready from me for your wisdom.
Regarding your wisdom's letter concerning the appointment of Mr. Matthias Erb, I have received it today, the date of this letter, and understood its content.

In response, I humbly inform your wisdom that, as I have so far (as my dear lord and friend, your wisdom's city clerk, well knows) handled this matter to the best of my ability, I will continue to not spare my effort and faithful diligence, so that your wisdom's request may be promptly fulfilled by me. Whatever then happens to me and would require a response, I will promptly report to your wisdom; for if I could do your wisdom a service and favor, I would be willing, eager, and entirely undeterred (ready to serve). I hereby humbly and kindly ask your wisdom to have me faithfully followed. May the faithful God and Father graciously preserve your wisdom through Christ, our Lord.
Dated Zurich in the Confederation, the 6th day of August in the year 1545. Your wisdom's always willing servant
To the learned, noble, steadfast, pious, prudent, and wise councilors of the city of Augsburg, his gracious, dear sirs.
